Name: Matsumae Kagura ( 松前神楽 )
Remarks: Originally performed at Matsumae Castle , chief residence of the Matsumae clan , the dance subsequently spread to other parts of Hokkaido where it picked up regional straits
Location: various parts of southeastern Hokkaido : Matsumae District , Hakodate , Otaru , Fukushima

Name: Noh Dance of Shimokita ( 下北の能舞 , shimokita no nōmai )
Date: From third day of New Year
Remarks: Theatrical yamabushi kagura consisting of ritual dances , military dances of battles between humans and demons and a lion dance . This is preceded by a group of local youths moving from house to house carrying a lion 's head representing gongen

Name: Unotori Dance ( 鵜鳥神楽 , unotori kagura )
Date: Various times , from January 8 to April
Remarks: Theatrical yamabushi kagura performed as a travelling tour through various villages and towns along the Sanriku Coast , from Kuji in the north to Kamaishi in the south . The dance has been designated under criteria 2 , 3

Name: Kuromori Kagura ( 黒森神楽 )
Remarks: Theatrical yamabushi kagura centered around gongen lion dances and also including ritual and masked dances . The dances are accompanied by small hourglass-shaped drums , flutes and bronze cymbals and distinct bird-style hats are used in some of them

Name: Hayachine Kagura ( 早池峰神楽 )
Date: July 31 , August 1 ; also on February 2 , latter part of April , middle of September , third Sunday in December ( Ōtsuganai ) ; January 3 , December 17 ( Take )
Remarks: A variety of masked dance including ritual , theatrical and wild pieces , comic dialogue and at the end a lion dance characteristic of the yamabushi tradition of northeast Japan . The Hayachine Kagura is represented by two kagura groups , Ōtsuganai and Take , with more or less identical performances . The one notable difference is that the masked used for the mountain kami are referred to as a in Ōtsuganai and as un in the Take tradition , forming the a-un syllables that feature in various Buddhist and Shinto contexts

Name: Ogatsu hōin Kagura ( 雄勝法印神楽 )
Date: 18th day of the second month ( Funatama Shrine ) ; 15th-16th day of the third month ( Isuzu Shrine ) ; 19th day of the third month ( Shirogane Shrine ) ; 8th day of the fourth month , once every three or four years ( Ishi Shrine ) ; 29th day of the fourth month , once every three or four years ( Shiogama Shrine )
Remarks: Theatrical yamabushi kagura including the Amano-Iwato story which is characteristic of kagura of western Japan . It is accompanied by two large ōdaiko drums and is first mentioned in a document from 1739

Name: Nekko Bangaku ( 根子番楽 )
Remarks: A form of yamabushi kagura performed as part of the Bon festival in August and as part of Yama Shrine 's festival in September . Locally it is referred to as bushi mai ( warrior dance ) , ara mai ( wild dance ) or shishi mai ( lion dance ) and is accompanied by large hourglass-type drum , flute and cymbals

Name: Horōsan no Shimotsuki Kagura ( 保呂羽山の霜月神楽 )
Remarks: A form of yudate kagura including 33 rituals performed over one night including a kagura dance in ancient manner . It is seen as a prayer for abundant crops and thanks for the harvest

Name: Honkai-bangaku Lion dance ( 本海獅子舞番楽 , honkai shishimai bangaku )
Date: Various times of the year , at the start of the year in January , July-September , November , December
Remarks: Intense lion dance performed by two people , one carrying a lion head the other under a sheet . Besides the lion dance there are other ceremonial and ritual dances , samurai dances and women dances . The designation has been designated under criteria 2 , 3

Name: Sugisawa Hiyama ( 杉沢比山 )
Date: August 15 ( main ) , also on August 6 ( preparation ) , 20 ( sending kami off )
Remarks: A type of yamabushi kagura that belongs to the bangaku kagura tradition of Aomori , Iwate , Akita and Yamagata Prefecture and consists of a series of masked dramas and ritual dances

Name: Tamashiki Shrine Kagura ( 玉敷神社神楽 , tamashiki jinja kagura )
Washinomiya Saibara Kagura ( 鷲宮催馬楽神楽 )
Edo no Sato Kagura ( 江戸の里神楽 ) or haji kagura
Remarks: Theatrical mime performed by shrines around Tokyo consisting of four groups : Wakayama shachū ( Taitō ) , Mamiya shachū ( Shinagawa ) , Matsumoto shachū ( Arakawa ) , Yamamoto shachū ( Inagi ) . The tradition is derived from Washi no Miya Kagura of Saitama and was introduced during the Enpō era . It received a revamping during the Meiji period resulting in a mix of classical ( koten ) kagura relating ancient myths , modern ( kindai ) kagura portraying medieval stories ( e.g . Rashōmon ) , otogi kagura of modern legends ( e.g . Momotarō ) , nō and kyōgen kagura

Name: Chigo no Mai of Kawaguchi ( 河口の稚児の舞 , Kawaguchi no chigo no mai )
Date: April 25 ( Magomi Festival ( 孫見祭 ) ) and July 28 ( Daidai Festival ( 太々御神楽祭 ) )
Remarks: Dance of about 10 young girls accompanied by drums , hourglass-shaped drums , and flutes considered as a type of daidai kagura . The dance has been designated under criteria 2 , 3

Name: Tōyama Shimotsuki Matsuri ( 遠山の霜月祭 , tōyama no shimotsuki matsuri )
Remarks: A form of yudate kagura consisting of various dances and dramas

Name: Tenryū Shimotsuki Kagura ( 天竜村の霜月神楽 )
Hana Matsuri ( 花祭 )
Ise Daikagura ( 伊勢太神楽 )
Remarks: A tradition of predominantly lion dances with some theatrical pieces and acrobatics added . They are used as purification ritual and to pacify spirits

Name: Okashira Shinji ( 御頭神事 , lit . ritual of the ( lions ' ) heads )
Remarks: Lion dance of a male and female lion by two men bearing torches , originally performed as purification ritual to cure the villagers of disease

Name: Ama Fūryū Odori and Kōdori dances ( 阿万の風流大踊小踊 , ama no fūryū odori kōdori )
Remarks: Two types of dances : odori danced in two rows employing fans to the accompaniment of song , hyoshigi , and shimedaiko , with lyrics originating in the Muromachi and early Edo period ; kōdori danced in a single row by about 8 dancers with lyrics after the Genroku era and with a lighter tone . Originally a prayer for rain , the dances are now performed as part of the shrine 's autumn festival . The dance has been designated under criteria 2 , 3
